summary:
Epistemic uncertainty is uncertainty due to lack of knowledge.

Epistemic uncertainty is uncertainty due to variation.

Aleatory uncertainty is uncertainty due to variation.

Aleatory uncertainty is uncertainty due to lack of knowledge.

Epistemic uncertainty is prevalent in the forensic evaluation of evidence.

There is no uncertainty in the forensic evaluation of evidence.

Aleatory uncertainty is prevalent in forensic evaluation of evidence.

Direct uncertainty relates to the object of uncertainty. An example is measurement uncertainty.

Direct uncertainty relates to a different object that affects the main object of uncertainty. An example is the robustness of the science underlying measurement uncertainty.

Indirect uncertainty relates to a different object that affects the main object of uncertainty. An example is the robustness of the science underlying measurement uncertainty.

Indirect uncertainty relates to the object of uncertainty. An example is measurement uncertainty.

The likelihood ratio is a tool for communicating uncertainty.

The likelihood ratio does not communicate uncertainty.

The likelihood ratio cannot be used for events that have happened in the past.

The likelihood ratio is not used in forensic science.

In forensic science, likelihood ratios are communicated as single values, ranges of values, and verbal statements.

In forensic science, likelihood ratios are communicated as single values only.

In forensic science, likelihood ratios are communicated as ranges of values only.

In forensic science, likelihood ratios are communicated as verbal statements only.
